@SecTPB
So you're not ripping and encoding from a broadcast?  Why all the commercials?

@James R. Bath
I'm ripping, but not encoding. This is the actual transport stream file, though I lowered the broadcast bitrate a bit to not make it TOO large. I then use it as my source to encode the 400p versions. Broadcasts on FiOS in my area run 480p and 720p in 60FPS in a modified MPEG-2 container that utilizes AVC. There's a lot of companies making the transition to this format since it is more efficient than MPEG-2 transport streams. Uses less data, increases broadcast quality, and bitrate can be adjusted with the right equipment. This is literally the exact broadcast with a 3500kbps reduction in bitrate. Instead of spending the time encoding it after ripping it, I simply cut the commercials from the stream and repack it, leaving only the event sequences with a H.264 TS Cutter.

^This saves time, meaning I can release instantly after broadcast, and if someone wants to re-encode it themselves, they have that option as the quality is near flawless with my minor bitrate reduction. Nothing beats a stream naturally 60FPS though. The smoothness is unreal if you've never tried it, but it CAN be difficult for many computers to process all 60FPS at once without dropped frames, causing a lag or stutter. That's why i encode a compact 400p version with everything I release, so those unfortunate enough to not be able to properly playback this file can still watch it, and I use very specific x264 settings during my 400p encodes to make them VERY watchable on even a large 1080p screen without much of an issue.
